>>52904789
When you enter a raid, there's a plus sign button on the right side above your roster. Pressing that button opens your friends list to invite from.

When you get invited to a remote raid, your radar thingy in the bottom right will turn orange, and the raid tab will show you which raid you're invited to. From there it's just a normal remote raid.

Work quickly in both cases, because remote raiders still have to get in during the two-minute lobby timer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52906255
Special Pokemon such as shines, costumes, and legendaries are exempt from roster cuts, unless you absolutely don't care for them
If you don't PvP, keep your highest-CP mon of each family and any perfect IVs, dump the rest
If you do PvP, use Poke Genie to evaluate each Pokemon's IVs, sort them according to the league you want to enter them in, then by IV rating, then level, basically keep whichever ones won't be a pain in the ass to raise
If you're not a collector, dump the shitmons as well
If you can, trade away anything that isn't an absolute shitmon instead of transferring it, you currently get an extra candy and a candy XL for trading

>FP Chesnaught is the best non-legendary, non-shadow, non-mega grass-type

tf? how is it better than FP Venu??

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52917708
They have the same ideal moveset, and since physical vs. special stats don't matter in GO, the fact that Chesnaught has biggest Attack and Defense than Venusaur has Sp. Attack and Sp. Defense (plus more HP) means it has better stats in every category. Also, Sceptile is more frail without significantly more DPS to consider it better than Chesnaught. Don't forget that Mega Venusaur and Mega Sceptile exist, though, along with Shadow Venusaur, Shadow Tangrowth, Kartana, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52917708
For gym/raid grass DPS, regular Chesnaught is strictly better than regular Venusaur by virtue of better base stats, but not as good as regular Sceptile.

>Chesnaught: 201/204/204 base stats
>Venusaur: 198/189/190 base stats
>Sceptile: 223/169/172 base stats

This is ignoring factors that may play into per-raid situations, primarily typing, since Chesnaught is Grass/Fighting, Venusaur is Grass/Poison, and Sceptile is pure grass, each having their own advantages and disadvantages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52917923
If we rank by TDO instead of DPS, Chesnaught is an impressive attacker.
It's a valuable addition to any new player's roster, but for long term players it doesn't represent an advantage in a battle system that strongly favours utilising multiple high DPS attackers, over fewer high TDO attackers.

https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>>52903274
If nothing else, what they could do is make use of the real evo mechanic for them. Evolve your Pokemon into Mega, you lose the original Pokemon, but it's Attack is transferred to the Mega (And it comes with a damage multiplier).
This fixes a lot of the issues with Megas. They'd now have a benefit beyond just being another checkmark, but they would also keep the idea of you wanting to breed the Pokemon before Mega Evolving it, it's just no longer mandatory.
The buff could either be in line with legendary held items (50%), or if we want to take Held Items into account to keep them in line with that, make it 25%. (25% + a 20% Held Item multiplicatively gets you exactly 50% extra)

>>52917111
>It goes against everything established in regards to the bonds between Pokémon and trainer in the anime, especially when you compare Goh to the other companions.
I get what you're saying and I agree with you, to an extent. I would've greatly preferred to see Goh use his Pokemon outside the lab. There were a few instances where he called upon them to help overcome an obstacle he and Ash faced. I would've loved more of this. I wanted to see Goh occasionally challenge gyms and enter contests to get stronger and strengthen his bond with his Pokemon. I love the idea of Goh having a variety of Pokemon from every region, but I'm not thrilled with the execution of the idea. I only take exception with the claim that Goh is an evil or selfish person when his Pokemon are well-cared for by him and others, and although we only see it every now and again, we do know that he spends time with them when he's at the lab, so we can assume it also happens off-screen. Ash has never been around someone with Goh's goal, so comparing Goh to his other friends and their catching habits isn't really fair. Goh does keep his Pokemon at the lab outside of their balls all the time, which is something Ash's companions couldn't do, but I wouldn't criticize them for that because their situations aren't comparable.

>The reason for the scarcity of insect fossil is the poor preservation potential of the insect's exoskeleton. Like other Arthropods, insects have an external skeleton called an exoskeleton. Unlike the thick and calcified trilobite exoskeleton, the insect exoskeleton is made of a thin, plastic-like material called chitin, along with a tough protein. This thin, waterproof covering simply does not preserve well in most oxygenated environments, making insect fossils sparse despite the tremendous number that could have been preserved. The exception is in fossil resinite (amber, by street name), where it is possible for even the minutest details to be preserved right down to fragments of DNA.
Amber can fossilize insects. While rare, it’s not impossible so you can’t completely dismiss fossilization.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52917912
>>52917947
The Destiny Knot ensures that an Egg will inherit 5 of their parent's randomly selected IVs instead of the usual 3. These IVs are selected from either parent, not just the one holding the Destiny Knot. If both parents had perfect IVs, you'd have a 1/6 chance of producing an Egg with a "perfect" 5 IV spread (assuming you don't care about SpA for a Cinderace).
A Power item can be used to ensure a specific IV always gets passed down, but this counts as one of the five inherited IVs. You can use it to improve your odds of an ideal spread but it can't guarantee one.

>>52911476
Speaking of this, how do sandwiches work on the multiplayer?
Does host need to make the sandwich or can any of the players pop it and they all get it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912347
If you do a sandwich together, everyone has to throw in at least one ingredient and one seasoning (though it really doesn't matter too much) then everyone makes it together on a mega sandwich. Everyone shares the same boosts for that sandwich, and making an individual sandwich on your own will only give yourself the boosts.
Usual strat is one player puts in herbs, everyone hunts and then that player resets if they didn't get what they want so nobody has to use up any.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912196
Whenever I encounter a shiny in Scarlet or Violet, I Google "Pokémon Name sv", e.g. "Riolu sv".

"sv" is a quick way to get Serebii's entry for that Pokémon in Scarlet/Violet loaded, and then check the wild Pokémon's learnset for its current level, as well as abilities that may be a factor.
E.g. I can't spore an insomniac Murkrow.
Specifying "sv" is to avoid getting entries for other games like SwSh, or other sites like Bulbapedia. It's specific to the game I'm playing.

posts.com:
So I have been thinking about more how much of a missed opportunity it was that they didn't release Ash-Greninja alongside Serena's Greninja.

Ash-Greninja is very popular and well known and is one of the most badass things Pokemon has produced, and its been disrespected a lot lately.

Here's a concept I had in mind for how Ash-Greninja could've been.

Neo-Champion Serena would have had the Shiny Greninja and it would've been a support like how Calem's currently is.

Instead of Calem, we get Ash and Ash-Greninja. Ash-Greninja would be a Special Striker.

Some moves I concepted are as follows:

>Water Shuriken
Works exactly like how the current Serena's Greninja's Water shuriken does, but does a little more damage.

>Cut
A powerful physical normal attack that hits a single target and never misses.

>Double Team
Works like how the current Shiny Greninja's Double Team works, but gives more speed and evasion and heals Ash-Greninja more.

>"Let-z Go!" or, "Iku-Z!"
A self-buff that grants Ash and Greninja insane speed and damage and will be the move that transforms Greninja into Ash-Greninja. This will make their damage strong enough to nearly one-shot any enemy, but can only be used once and only affects Ash. This is partially based off how Ash-Greninja was so powerful that it almost destroyed Diantha's Mega Gardevoir, if he didn't pass out.

>Sync Move: Bond Phenomenon Water Shuriken
Ash-Greninja's Sync Move is none other than the big golden Water Shuriken he summoned against Alain in the Kalos League Finals. Imagine if something like that actually hit? This is a guaranteed one-shot if it connects, but comes at the cost of 50% of Ash and Greninja's current health. This can only be used if Ash has transformed Greninja into Ash-Greninja using "Iku-Z!"/"Let-z Go!"

I haven't designed the grid yet, but I was thinking that some of the grid could be used to power up his Water Shuriken and Cut, and maybe something that guarantees a set amount of dodges from Double Team.

Cont.

The story for this event will mix the games and the anime, and focus on Ash and Serena's childhood and bond.

It will show Serena getting upset at losing to something and Ash cheering her up, and the two of them using the power of their respective Greninjas to overcome this threat. This impresses Diantha who gives them a chance to double battle her and a surprise cameo in Alain. Ash and Serena beat them, and are named the Neo Champions.

The ending has Ash and Serena celebrating, and Serena promising that she will stick by Ash no matter what, since she now feels like she's worthy enough to stand by his side as an equal.

I didn't want to overload the story with Amourshipping but still keep enough of it there to make fans happy.

>>52883928
There’s no “too late” for this game until they announce EOS is on the horizon, which probably won’t be for at least another year or two.

The game is easy enough that you can clear the hardest content after 2-3 months of playing, and there’s no PVP so it doesn’t matter if you don’t have all the best units. Once you’ve hit that level the game doesn’t demand much of your time, it’s about 10 minutes to do all the dailies and maybe half an hour to clear champion stadium/battle villa/legendary gauntlet whenever they drop.

Game’s mostly for pulling for your waifus/husbandos and seeing cute story snippets every once in a while. If that sounds like it could appeal to you there’s no harm in giving it a shot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52879198
>If Square Enix made Pokemon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52883091
Eat food when you need a specific effect like encounter power to find a rare spawn easier, raid power to get bonus rewards from raids, etc.
Custom sandwiches are the best since you can make basically any type and ability combo you want. The premade recipe book is good for main game and searching for a specific ability if you don't know how the sandwich system works.
Buy ingredients like whenever, I would buy like 10 of everything you don't have yet when you see it.

Eventually if you want to go for shinies, these recipes attached are convenient. There's a dozen different resources scattered around online for other more specific recipes, so just Google search for a specific ability + type if you're curious or try to theory craft a sandwich at this link
https://cecilbowen.github.io/pokemon-sandwich-simulator/

posts.name: cge0361

>>52911327
>What kind of cliffhanger does it end on?
It isn't a cliffhanger per se, but it's only the completion of the first story arc of an originally intended three, so there's a lot of stuff that's clearly setup for later resolution that's left open-ended. (It was supposed to be a graphic novel kind of thing but the original character designer and artist dipped about a dozen pages into the first chapter and the author was nine chapters deep, so finishing the first arc felt like the best compromise between not throwing all the work away and not committing to more than the extant work required.)

The problem/reason for that is that the author is a nerd and actually wrote about a dozen things and they're all set in the same continuity, so even ignoring the bits that were for the intended latter two parts, there's also a lot that references other stuff, including stuff that wasn't yet written when it came out.

All that aside, it's a couple dozen chapters of slice-of-life that takes an objective look at the gardevoir-waifu cliche, starter pokemon loyalty issues, where pokemon fit into a human family structure, the innately speculative fiction aspects of things like parallel worlds and transient land masses (as are canon in Pokemon but of a different sort here), the pressures of organized competition, latent psychic emanations, ghosts with attitude, adverse possession law, wildlife management, identity theft, and treatments for acute hypothermia.

But mostly people click on it because "Gardevoir" is in the tags.

>>52910812
It may no longer be an issue but AO3 used to be notorious for a long sign-up queue. Apply well before you want to post there.

>zwcsp

>The closest was all the way in Sunnyville on the other side of the region. And that was a trip his parents weren’t willing to make.
Are you intending to imply that one must have a Professor-assigned starter to participate in League? Canon has people with pokemon from any origin; the Hero's Journey of Red, Ash, etc. justifies having a pokemon with viable BST.

I feel like this infodump should've been the entirety of Chapter 1 after the funeral scene cold open. As a bulky flashback, you could show rather than tell Travis's efforts to acquire a starter, and time-skip as needed to need only portray "the good stuff." Like, one scene of him trying to get a trip to Sunnyville, another where he's doing yard work to earn money to mail-order some pokeballs and then fails to catch anything with the one/few he gets, and so on. Another where he tries to borrow one and gets told plainly that his acquaintances won't entrust him with the care of their pokemon for several reasons giving him reason to introspect—that could be where he suspends the idea and it lingers and gnaws at him in the background till the expiration of Arcanine.

Instead we're spending a lot of time trying to sell the premise when either the reader is already willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of making acquisition of a starter a momentous (and hitherto belated) event in Travis's life, or it points out the contrivance and makes it more awkward.

The rest of the chapter works well enough, although maybe something more interesting could be done to get them together without it being "that simple." Travis could've lost his keys or phone and had to go back maybe, or leave the encounter a bust but later (after acquiring a starter) Travis goes up the mountain again to grind some levels and encounters it again, and then tries to add it to the roster.

>>52912683
> I really wanted to get things off the ground
The lack of immediate relevance of Travis's backstory prevents it from taking flight. A flashbacks sequence can _show_ the key events leading to Travis being here as he is and feeling the way that he does. Alternatively, the "fill that in later" path, would be to just play the funeral scene straight, have Travis choose to go for a walk instead of to return, and then use the walk as a way to establish. Maybe he sees some "first route" kinds of pokemon and laments that he couldn't even catch one of those when he did manage to get some balls. He could see someone with a quality starter and rue that his parents never agreed to a vacation trip that would include a stop at a Lab. And as he goes deeper into the wild and higher up the hill he could start to realize the danger he's put himself into and _then_ contemplate if even having a starter he might be as unprepared as he is right now. Stuff like that gives lots of opportunity for building tension while establishing backstory while the main story doesn't break stride.

>>52913832
I get what you mean with the pacing, I should really try to stop writing giant chunks of introspection like that. However one thing I can't compromise is the trip into the wilderness being incidental. It's very important that it was a conscious choice, since when I came up with the idea for the story, one of the main themes was to be complacency, and with that, a recurring thematic development of someone wanting to do a thing and then just doing it. I was explicitly trying to fit that kind of development twice into the first chapter just to establish it as strongly as possible, because I had planned to use it for future arcs and other characters, applying it in different ways and so on. That's part of why I was hesitant to open with a big flashback, because it doesn't let me establish the thematics I want quite as strongly out of the gate. I could go way heavier on the complacency, to be sure, but ultimately that would end up not hitting the tone I wanted for this first chapter

In any case, all that introspection is definitely due to get cut up and spaced out to make way for more actual things happening

"... And this is Master Florian. Everyone, please get along with him!"

After being introduced to my homeroom class, I quickly darted my eyes to find a place to sit. Nemona eagerly waved me over, sitting in the back corner of the room. Kind of weird, since I thought she'd be interesting in learning more about Pokemon considering her love of battling. I smiled at her and sat next to her in the back, looking forward with a rush of excitement as class began.

A few minutes in, I heard a weird noise. I looked over, seeing Nemona was making a clicking noise with a mechanical pencil to get my attention. When she saw me, she winked at me and moved her hand--my eyes traveled to follow it. She had unbuttoned one small part of her white school shirt and pulled it forward to show me the inside; I could see one of her boobs. She quickly refastened it and smirked at me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Potential Status Rework:
So some baseline concepts I set out to address:
>Sleep: if abusable, is a pain in the ass.
Original gamefreak fix: lower accuracy of sleep moves, greatly limit distribution of consistent sleep. Issue mostly hinges on the inability to act coupled with RNG of when you wake.
>Paralysis: Sleep's shithead cousin
Use as a slowdown status is great, but the RNG chance to do nothing at all makes paralysis inconsistent and makes the rewards for inflicting it not something to plan around.
>Freeze: Sleep but different (they really were preoccupied with ways to take away turns in Gen 1, weren't they?)
A status with no status move, meaning it MUST be inflicted by chance. Underutilized, RNG-reliant. I think I've seen two dozen actual Freezes in my entire career, and I've played since Gold release.
>Burn: Okay status
No notes.
>Poison: Toxic is good but limited in use, and base poison is pretty shit
These are the focuses of my initial rework, as I was not too preoccupied with volatile status like Confusion or Attraction - they occupy the same niche as Paralysis, and get more complex.
I set out with the intention to make status less of an RNG fest and more of a conscious choice and reward.

So my first thoughts were to incorporate the changes proposed by PLA.
>Drowsy
Excellent mechanic, but again leans on the RNG aspect. I've removed this and adapted it.
>Frostbite
Fixed Freeze. No way about it. Excellent design.

And I came up with a system to inflict status to allow more ways to interact with them without needing to fuck around with actual status moves or random chance effects.

1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912369
>Sleep
Grass types are immune to drowsy / sleep
>No point system. Solely tied to status moves. Moves that would inflict Sleep now inflict Drowsy. Drowsy Pokemon hit with these moves are put to Sleep.
This makes Sleep an easily achievable goal two-punch goal, and balances the opportunity cost of the status with the potential benefit to be gained.
>Drowsy
>Drowsy Pokemons' moves have a flat 10% accuracy reduction (for example, a 90% accuracy move is now 80% accuracy). Additionally, Drowsy Pokemon take 25% increased damage from the next hit they receive after becoming Drowsy
An immediate payoff for investing the time to inflict Drowsy, but nothing crazy.
>Sleep
Sleep turns now follow this setup:
>Turn 1: Fast Asleep, no chance to awake. Moves like Sleep Talk still work.
>Turn 2: 65% chance to wake, move used on waking has 75% of base accuracy. This works out to turn 2 being a 50/50 of waking AND hitting your waking move.
>Turn 3: 100% chance to wake, no changes to accuracy
>Pokemon leaving Sleep are returned to Drowsy status, and cannot be put to Sleep for 3 turns.
>Accuracies of moves used against Sleeping Pokemon are increased by a flat 5%.

So, now Sleep is a telegraphed, earned status that has a lot going on under the hood rather than just being "you can't move for 2-4 turns". This all works out to:
>Invest two turns to put an opposing Pokemon to sleep
>As a result, it is expected the opposing Pokemon will have approx. 1.5 of the next 3 turns to use, a net loss of 1-2 turns.
>And even after waking, the Pokemon remains weakened in a Drowsy state.

This is all a little heavily designed, but Sleep really wasn't well thought-out and never has been. Hiding behind low-accuracy moves doesn't change how busted sleep is fundamentally.

2/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912381
>Paralysis
Fighting types are immune to dazed/paralysis
>No longer centered around electric types - now based around Flinches and Critical Hits
This makes Paralysis an evergreen status, something heavily needed by non-elemental types.
>Dazed
>Pokemon that have been flinched or critically hit become dazed. Dazed Pokemon lose 25% Speed. Moves used against Dazed Pokemon have increased critical hit ratios. Flinching or Critting a Dazed Pokemon pushes this status to Paralyzed
>Paralyzed
>Speed reduced 50%, Priority moves used by Paralyzed Pokemon lose 1 priority.
>Moves against Paralyzed Pokemon have even higher critical hit ratios
>Accuracies of moves used against Paralyzed Pokemon are increased by a flat 10%

This makes Paralysis a strong status for non-elemental types, where flinch and crits reign supreme. It most notably hands a status to the Normal and Fighting types. I will most likely not make moves like Fake Out have their flinches contribute to the status, but I can still see that as something to leave in to make Fake Out a more potent opening shot. If I did something like that, I'd drop the base damage of the move to keep it from being as good of a revenge kill move to clarify the move's identity as an opening shot / setup rather than a closer.

Some electric status moves will still inflict Paralysis directly. Maybe a fighting status move to inflict this status as well, as this new layout fits nicely with Fighting's identity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912394
Similar to Paralysis, I'm adding routes to status that AREN'T RNG reliant or hard-linked to status moves. Burn, Frostbite, and Poison statuses are inflicted in Tiers, and the current tier is determined by the amount of status points on a Pokemon (invisible value). This makes it possible to use status without forcing the player into status moves. It also greatly rewards committing to a particular status.

>Burn / Frostbite
Identical twins of Status. Fire types are immune to Burn, Ice types are immune to Frostbite.
Burn is inflicted by reaching [threshold] of Burn status points. Fire status moves inflict a set amount of status points, but damaging fire moves also deal some Burn status points. Some Fire moves deal more Burn status, and as a tradeoff deal less direct damage. Same philosophy for Frostbite, but for Ice moves. Ice receives frost status moves a la Will-O-Wisp.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 50% target's maximum HP, II reach at points = 100% target's maximum HP
>I: Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 25% increased damage. DoT moves (like fire spin) deal 50% increased damage, both on use and on recurring damage. Burnt/Frostbitten Pokemon take 1/16 maximum HP damage per turn, doubled to 1/8 if the afflicted Pokemon would be weak to that elemental type.
>II: Attack (Burn) / Special Attack (Frostbite) lowered 50%, speed lowered 25%. Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 50% increased damage. Status cures used on Tier II only reset the status to Tier I.

Tiering in this manner makes these statuses excellent on the offense. Elemental moves that push an opponent under the 50% HP line set you up for the finishing stroke the next turn regardless of opponents' recoveries, and opponents that can restore their health to outpace this are eventually forced into Tier II, where they can again be set up for a finishing stroke and are even harder to cleanse of status.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912408
>Poison
Poison and Steel types are immune to Poison
Poison follows the same principles as Burn/Frostbite, wherein a set amount of Poison status points determine the status of the Pokemon.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 30% target's maximum HP, II reached at points = 60% target's maximum HP, Toxic reached at points = 120% of target's maximum HP
>I: Deals a flat amount of Poison damage each turn (as if a low-power Poison move were used against the opponent, rather than a % of maximum HP)
>II: Deals 1/8 maximum HP DoT per turn. Damaging poison moves lower Poisoned Pokemon's Defense and Special Defense 1 stage on hit.
Curing Poison II reverts to Poison I
>Toxic: Takes 1/4 Maximum HP DoT per turn. This damage increases by an additional 1/8 Maximum HP each turn, increasing the Toxic Counter. Curing Toxic reverts to Poison II, but does NOT reset the Toxic Counter.

The best stab I could take at updating Poison to not be just boring chip damage. Tier I is excellent at dealing with squishier Pokemon, with the potential for the flat damage to actually deal MORE than % HP damage would. Tier II is then available if the target is bulkier, and rewards continued use of Poison moves as stat droppers. If the opponent is truly nasty, Toxic comes online and is inevitable, even if the opponent has a way to scrub status.

5/6, missed numbering 4 but oh well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912485
I suppose I'd refine my goal to be "defining the RNG risk-taker". For example, in the case of Sleep, the Sleep inducer is taking a 75% chance (Sleep Powder, in this instance) that they will cripple their opponent for 2-4 turns. The slept Pokemon now has to take a risk to even play the game further, unless the player switches it out. In most scenarios, 2-4 turns of sleep is a death sentence or a huge setup opportunity, making Sleep basically a higher-accuracy OHKO move with even bigger potential repercussions.
In this scenario, we instead have an immediate payoff for attempting Sleep that still allows the opponent the opportunity to control their Pokemon and assume their own risks without being forced into a specific path. This also means we can heighten the accuracy of Drowsy/Sleep moves, as we no longer have to worry about the feast/famine Sleep moves inherently create. The final rework to Sleep turns means we now have a consistent pattern, with specific, well-defined risks associated with each turn to engage with. Sure, this makes turn 2 a coin-flip, but in reality Sleep was always a series of coinflips - I've simply made the Pokemon more likely to wake, with the downside that they may still lose the turn's move.

I've been leaning a lot on exactly that thought process - borrowing a little from card games, other RPGs, and a little tiny bit from MOBAs. Games are popular for a reason, no sense in letting them slide by without analyzing what can be brought into Pokemon without wrecking the style.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52913219
I bring up card games in particular because Pokemon shares a lot with them. A team of Pokemon can be reasonably compared to a deck of cards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52913233
Valid. I think you're seeing those parallels as deckbuilding and teambuilding "rhyme" in a lot of ways. The ability to compose a team or deck is limited only by the availability of options, and Pokemon delivers in spades (and just like card games, Pokemon suffers from power creep AND centralizing of the meta to strategies that for the most part call for silver bullets or direct countermeta builds). Pokemon has this easier and harder due to only having six (or 24 if you view it at the movepool-level, or 30 if you include abilities) slots instead of 40+ - not to mention lack of rematches in online play makes it hard to "sideboard" Pokemon.
Similarities, but also signficant differences.

most of my ideas are visually based, since my gripe is that natures don't present themselves as actually affecting the perception of a pokemon beyond its numbers

a third idea could be modifying the pitch and speed of cries based on nature

Future

>Hydreimon

>Ursasting - Bug/Normal
>Truleewoodo - Grass/Rock
>Mizzapius - Electric/Ghost
>Crabroiler - Water/Fire
>Starester - Normal
>Hauntricity - Ghost/Poison
>Clervorges - Psychic/Fairy
>Hialtari - Ice/Flying
Geeta wants a stronger ace and creates an ultimate form for Glimmora
>Glimaxim - Rock/Poison
Penny wishes for Eevee to be as viable as its evolutions and creates
>Eeveeon - Normal

>gym leader ace paradoxes have the ability “Spotlight” that boosts their best stat if they’re sent in as the final Pokemon standing on a full team
>Glimaxim has the ability “Earth Charge” which is Levitate + a full stat boost each time it’s triggered
>Eeveeon has the ability “Family Link” which makes it immune to Fighting attacks and provides a full stat boost each time one is attempted
>Booster Energy works on the gym leader paradoxes but not on the champ/penny ones

Next, the new time themed paradoxes
>Wise Eyes - Psychic/Normal - Seeakazam

And finally the legendaries, the first two of which have been discussed to death

And finally, the mysterious traveler from the past OR future

>>52914940
The revelation of their ‘real’ names will not change their species or Pokedex data, though the obvious implication is that going forward they will use these names when they appear instead of their codenames. The only ones that will go by their ‘real’ names in the dex/species listing for this game are the 10 ace ones that don’t have codenames to begin with. Can’t speak to the DLC’s creative process but I heard the base game’s paradoxes referred to by their real names before launch, I’m almost certain the codenames came second.

>>52915023

>>52913357
I think you're just looking at it from a coomer (understandable, she's one of the best pokégirls) and, dare I say, slightly misogynistic perspective?
>Wife Beater/Vest Combo
Not as fashionable as other female protagonists, but it's practical and looks still looks good. The colour combo of black and white was probably intentional.
>Trucker Hat
She's the only pokégirl in the main series that wears a baseball cap, this just makes her seem more mature and confident. It suggests she has the same drive, competitiveness and lust for glory as the male characters like Ash Ketchum or Red. She's following in their footsteps (narratively, not consciously emulating them as idols) to be the very best.
>Daisy Dukes, maybe homemade
>combat boots
If you're going hiking long distances, shorts and sturdy boots just seem like common sense.

>Combat Boots with Red Laces
>She spilled blood for her race.
What? Explain this one to me, I don't get the reference.

TLDR: Hilda/White just has a mature, sexy and practical design compared to other femprotags, which is why she's coomerbait. But to project other stuff onto a character is poor form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Self-Destruct and Explosion should have the same base power but Explosion should be a special fire-type move. They should both keep the defensive stat reducing stealth effect from before the nerf.

“Never miss” moves like Swift should still hit its target during moves like Fly and Dig like they did in Gen 1. It’s less about making sense and more about buffing underused moves for balance in a way that keeps the spirit of the move.

Tackle should have 35 base power with 95 accuracy like it originally had. It’s supposed to be a basic but mediocre move that weak Pokémon start out with. You’re supposed to be happy to get rid of it with something better. Buffing it to 50 is dumb and makes Nuzlocking Gen 5 a pain in the ass.

Bug should be super effective against poison-type like it was in Gen 1. Less about making sense and more about balance since bug-type is so fucking shit.
>make fairy-type
>give them resistance to bug just to make sure bug-type will always be shit
JUST

Moves like Sonic Boom and Dragon Rage should just do damage equal to the user’s move like Seismic Toss and Nightshade. Having a move only do 20 or 40 damage is really worthless outside of the first hour or two in the game. They’re also both equally worthless in competitive regardless of the generation, if that counts for anything.

Rock Smash should drop defense 100% of the time. The move is weak as shit and buffing it wouldn’t make any impact in competitive play. As it stands, the move is a shitty version of Power-Up Punch. And yeah, not everything should be balanced for competitive but shit like Constrict (10 base power?????) should at least work 100% of the time.
>Gen 1: lowers speed; 33% chance
>Gen 2-7: lowers speed; 10% chance
>Gen 8+: the move does not exist
LMAO. I get that some moves are meant to be weak to give them a niche but at least DON’T FUCKING NERF THEIR EFFECT WHEN THEY’RE ALREADY A WORTHLESS MOVE

Nah. Just a very dark point on the timeline that we knew had already happened to a point.

When the world was very old, people and Pokemon lived inseparably, even indistinguishably as people wielded magic as much as Pokemon did, and together they created impressive structures that that are now mysterious ruins.

Some time after that, humans developed lethal weapons and became violent towards each other, and towards Pokemon as an exploitable resource, and pokemon-human relations devolved into a mutual aggression based on fear. As the separation grew so too did ignorance and superstition, and especially strong Pokemon begin to be worshipped as wrathful gods.

Some time since, a shaky reunion began, where Pokemon would ally themselves with humans again, but only if they first showed their worth. Moves as things Pokemon can be taught is also pioneered at this time, for instance Koga says Toxic is 400 years old.
It is at the very end of this long period that the first pokeballs were made and Pokemon begin to be seen more like fancy animals and less like dangerous Yokai that cause trouble but sometimes become cronies of great warriors. Basically, PLA is the story about how a time-stolen kid turned PokeWorld from SMT IV into Pokemon.

Within the next 200 years, pokeballs enter mass production and Pokemon and human societies have started to reintegrate, though Pokemon and humans do still have separate societies, and Pokemon still insist their human partner be worthy. Scientist begin researching the magical abilities of Pokemon. Some have success in replicating feats of old, for instance Magearna as a modern take on Golurk.

Within the last 50 years, PokeBall distribution went global, modernizing even regions as remote as Unova.

And within the last 10, technology based on Pokemon abilities rapidly begin to emerge, such as teleportation and fossil resurrection, resulting in a major technological boom.

Then Gen 1.

The main colour of the Pokemon must match the primary ball colour

The most elegant way to implement it would be having the idea of some in-game "official ruleset" for formal matches (Gym Leaders, E4 and competitive trainers like Nemona) that would mandate no items in battle (maybe with the exception of Battle Items because then what would the point of them be, even though they're overpowered as shit) and set mode.
There's not really a point though, the only way to meaningfully make the games more difficult is self-imposed playstyles, better game design (managing the level curve, better sets) and most importantly better AI. The fact that Game Freak balances around just giving the AI less options instead of actually improving it is embarrassing. Penny's fight being a complete joke (even more than you'd expect from an Eeveelution team) because she just has all of her Pokémon spam Baby-Doll Eyes is inexcusable. You can't make the game harder if the game itself doesn't know how to play the game.

>>52856078
Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. Or you could just decide that G/S/C is 100% noncanon and is fully replaced by the similar-but-slightly-different HG/SS content. Either way the idea of steel types being " recently discovered" doesn't work if you allow for the type chart to be something that exists within canon rather than a game extraction, because then the nature of reality somehow changes as pokemon researchers discover things. The setting turns into madness where subjective reality trumps scientific rigor and it gets worse then harder you try to make it make sense. Best to just ignore the retcon.

Pokemon is at its core a huge complex game of rock paper scissors. Things keep changing and then the counterplay adapts and this repeats.

As an example, Hydreigons started running terra-steel to deal with Sylveon, Sylveons started running terra-fire to deal with terra-steel Hydreigon, Hydreigons have no started running terra-water to counter terra-fire Sylveon. The cat and mouse continues to evolve.

Open team sheets put you on a (mostly) level playing field with the top player cliques that will give their friends info on your team between sets. They can still tell them rough stat spreads ("his X outsped my 112 Y so he probably has at least Z speed EVs", etc.) but it's better than "hey the guy you're about to fight has a one off gimmick that will sweep you if you don't know about it." So yes, surprise gimmicks won't work, but simultaneously having a large friend group won't provide and advantage. It's a more level playing field.

Knowing all of the rules/mechanics doesn't necessarily mean you know what the "optimal" build/playstyle is, assuming such a thing even exists. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52907804
For Cyclizar, Shed Tail + Regenerator is just broken.
Shed Tail means it loses 50% HP, and Regen means it gets 33% back. So it effectively only loses 17% HP to get an ally in for free.
Possibly better than free if the sub doesn't break on turn 1.

For Annihilape, it has perfect coverage with Ghost/Fighting. Rage Fist has 50 BP and increases by 50 every time Annihilape takes a hit (doesn't reset if it switches). Get hit once and it's 100 BP, hit twice and it's 150, 3 times and it's 200, etc., capping at 350.
Annihilape isn't likely to get to that 350 cap, but it hits like a truck even at 150 and it has enough bulk to take some hits easily.
And to top it off, it has Drain Punch to heal and take more hits, and Bulk Up to eat more (physical) hits in the future.

They're not as blatantly broken as Chi-Yu, but still pretty brutal. They deserve a suspect, not a quickban.

Autism is very much a spectrum lol some people are a lot more high functioning than others. Not to sound like a pick me or "not like other girls" but I hold a job and pay my own bills despite the difficulties my autism presents me with and looking at my roommate makes me relieved I didn't turn out like that.

I don't think that is any small feat and you should be proud that you can stand on your own. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pryce -> Chuck -> Jasmine feels the most right, imho. It smoothers both levels and makes narrative bit more bearable by putting sustainable amount of things between two TR encounters.
One can also do Chuck -> Pryce -> Jasmine for early Fly, but also it makes Amphy sidequest feel awkward - you leave sick, potentially dying Pokemon suffer longer to go and fuck around with TR and Pryce.

You can also go and explore Lighthouse after beating Chuck but honestly it's even more weird and then you need to backtrack for medicine.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52918594
If you're doing Chuck > Pryce > Jasmine you can just do the Lighthouse as soon as you reach Olivine, trigger the sidequest, surf to Cianwood get the medicine, do Chuck's Gym, Fly back to Olivine and deliver the medicine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52918486
Whatever the badge order is on your badge screen. Which means that you
>Go to Chuck and pick up the medicine for Amphy while you're there
>Go back to Jasmine and battle her now that she's not too worried about an important Pokemon
>Head on towards Pryce, allowing you to roll through the nearby Ice Path and head to Blackthorn to round things out immediately afterward

Honestly, even though I understand perfectly that you can do them in whatever order, this always seemed the most obviously correct way to me. Not only does the game display them in that order, but it's just the smoothest path through. You go west to go see Chuck and then you just make your path eastward, knocking over everyone still in your way until you've thrashed Clair.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52918602
That's also an option, just do Pryce between Amphy sidequest and Jasmine.

...m
Man, there's surprisingly a lot of depth and options in doing all of it. One can also just go and poke Gyarados early to get scale and trade it for exp share early. And then on top of it are berries, goldenrod stuff etc to squeeze in between.
I guess that's why I love GSC. Midgame is just running around doing all the small activities that add up to experience.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

Can someone tell me what's going through his brain? Why is it seemingly impossible to give their fanbase what they want? How is this guy in charge?

I understand that Pokémon is a massive brand, and that they can lowball everything, because there will always be the next generation of kids that will play it for the brand alone, along with the hardcore whales that will buy anything with a Pokémon label. But is that really an excuse to downgrade and cut corners? Do they think that Pokémon is to big to fail, so that they don't have to put any effort into anything?

I think Lego and The Pokémon Company are very similar. Lego started out as a kids brand, but as time went by, Adult fans started to become the main fambase and consumers, (AFOL/adult fan of lego). It took ages for Lego to realise this, but they eventually started to cater to their adult fanbase, as they became aware that AFOL's and collectors are the main consumers of Lego.

Pokémon KNOWS Kanto is their most profitable region, because it's what ADULTS love. They just can't help themselves but pander to it. It's time for them to take the next step, based on this logic, stop downgrading the newer games and regions, and you you will see profits behind your compression, because EVERYONE likes quality.

>>52912396
the more I think, the more it fits
Sturdy means they can't be OHKOd, meaning they can be relied on to get at least one hit in against even the strongest of foes, and makes them generally just more reliable defensively
they have access to multi-target moves like Rock Slide and Earthquake, and Bulldoze at least can be learned without even needing TM (Rock Slide also but only going off the PLA learnset, so probably not realistic), which I assume would be important since they're probably operating on a budget against more sophisticated foes. Smack Down is also useful for taking care of flying mons, and making them vulnerable to the mass-hitting Bulldoze.
Stealth Rock can make enemy reinforcements a bit easier to deal with (though likely won't ever trivialize them since Pokémon weak to Rock likely won't be used much against them)
SD/Explosion is a powerful last resort and not exactly unheard of among their type of group
Geodude doesn't evolve until level 25, but gets access to its final evolution immediately after, since they are a large organization they have no worries about finding another member to trade, having a bread-and-butter Pokémon thay requires this also would help build a sense of camaraderie among them
Of course, a bunch of Geodude spamming Bulldoze would probably do considerable damage to each other, so they'd probably want to get their hands on Rock Slide if they can manage, but a fierce blow at the enemy at the expense of collateral damage isn't a line they're unwilling to cross if necessary
The above factors as well as Geodude's relative abundance in its preferred habitats should make a convincing enough argument that this would absolutely be their main grunt-tier Pokémon

>>52914363
I believe the typing of the Geodude, their abundance lending themselves to being used en masse instead of a few more properly-trained units, and their explosive moves, would lead to Quagsite being a common counter - a good few Pokémon can have the ability Damp, but for many it is a hidden ability while Wooper can get it more commonly - and for that matter, Wooper and even its evolved form would be generally more easy to come by than alternatives such as Swampert.
Its more defensive stat distribution lends it to tanking more hits from the Taliban's attack-at-any-cost strategies, and with access to moves like Muddy Water and Earthquake through level up, it can make quick work of the hordes of weak, dispoable Geodude, with Damp stifling any attempts at some good-ol-fashioned suicide bombing while it is active. These Pokémon can be brought in by invaders en masse and evolved fully by level 20, but the caveat is that their water typing gives them special needs. Although it isn't unheard of for them to traverse dry, hot, sandy terrain (they can be found in max raid dens in the dusty bowl of Galar), they spend most of their time submerged in cold water so will need an oasis to retreat to between battles - this ties the bases they can be stationed in to a few areas that are probably already well known and fought over due to the scarcity of freshwater in the desert, so the area will have to be well defended.
[cont]

>>52914830
Likely counters to Quagsire employed by the Taliban would be Maractus or Cacturne, with their supereffective typing, access to sand veil or water-aborbing abilities, and ease of finding in the desert. These aren't without drawbacks, though, as Maractus is known for its dancing and musical proclimity, while music is outright banned by the taliban. Cacturne, meanwhile, would be strong enough to give their Geodude serious trouble when attempting to catch it, and also has a habit of ganging up on and stalking travellers and waiting until they're too weak to fight back before going in for the kill - whether they'd be seen as a valuable natural barrier to invaders or a threat to the Taliban in and of themselves depends on how the native mujahideen would have adapted to their presence in the region throughout history. Their best option would be catching the weaker Cacnea instead and training them up, but since it evolves at level 32 it requires a bit more investment than their Geodude and would probably be used in a more limited capacity so they can focus their training on a few units instead of trying to spread it out and raise up multiple (though it would have an easy time training against the wild Geodude due to double supereffectivity).
Their limited numbers would mean that the invaders could focus their attacks on the few cacti out on the battlefield, and you just know they'd be running Ice Beam or Icy Wind on their Quagsire
[cont]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52882568
>Lucario
Yeah pretty much. It hogs some good moves to itself, steals signatures from others (i.e., Bonemerang), and prevents us from finally getting a dedicated Special oriented fighting type. I don't really hate other fighting types, I more or less feel indifferent about some designs that don't appeal to me. I just want to see
>actual martial arts inspired brawlers again
>creativity with moves/abilities/themes
or ideally both. CC and Superpower and all other "burst of power" moves are so generic and devoid of what made the type unique in the early generations. I want some new punching moves, grappling effects, kicks, chops, etc. Where are our clerical/pivot support that can pull all sorts of hijinks like force an opponent out with a red card, or enforce rules like Inverse battles or auto-trick rooms?

>>52822483
The first fanfic I ever read when I was 12 was an Altoshipping fic called "Guardian of the Chosen One" by XD-385. It gets a bit insane with a dark shonen plot where Ash basically discovers he has Goku-esque superpowers (because he's the "Chosen One" mentioned in the Orange Islands), but it's a guilty pleasure that I still enjoy. There's only a couple nsfw chapters sprinkled throughout a much larger story; it takes place during Ash's Hoenn journey, and Ash finds himself missing Latias so much that he decides to go back and visit her in Alto Mare. He and Latias reconnect, have sex, have two shiny Lati babies, and eventually get married. And I LOVED all of it. I should really re-read it again sometime.
https://www.fanfiction.net/s/11010948/1/Guardian-of-the-Chosen-One

>>52882540
>>52882547
>>52882549
>bullshit schema the userbase comes up with
Character Tags are completely standard, as well as Pairings which are regularized to [Character A]/[Character B] for romance and [Character A]&[Character B] for friendship. From there, freeform tags (user submitted) are corrected/Linked by Tag wranglers to a standard form if they exist. If you tag something "[Character]'s Daddy Issues", your local tag wrangler will have that become a subtag to "Daddy Issues" and "Parental Issues", so if you search those tags, you'll still find the original fic. Mistagged fics are flagged by wranglers/standard users and the authors will be asked to fix them in egregious cases. If these things haven't happened, it's either because of the fic hasn't been gotten to, or the fandom isn't popular enough to have wranglers (who are just local fandom volunteers). Fandoms from there with very popular tropes or AUs will then gain fandom-specific tags. For the Pokemon anime " Ash Ketchum Has Aura Powers" is a popular tag, with a subtag "Aura Guardian Ash Ketchum" (since not every fic with Ash having Aura powers is him as an Aura Guardian). It also has a whole legion of synonyms that wranglers have tagged, such as
>Aura User Ash
>aura user!ash
>Aura!Ash
>AuraAsh
All of these were user-submitted tags that were made synonyms of the overarching tag for you to search. Any other tags from there are going to ones too specific to the story that the author still felt it important for you to know, which while yes can be excessive at times, does not make searching any harder.
Ao3 may be dense and the user tags at times way too long and unnecessary, however, finding what you like is not its problem in the slightest. Any issue that exists in Ao3's searchability is present in other sites as well. You just need to learn how to use its interface.
Source: Long time user of Ao3, Fimfiction, and FFN and former tag wrangler for the former.

>>52882370
There are no rules on Fimfiction. There are no rules moderators follow when deciding to enforce their will upon the site. Meta fics (about fimfiction and its users) are supposedly not allowed, except they are, unless staff don't like them. Making a group for the explicitly stated purpose of harassing authors and mocking stories with bad reddit scores is allowed, unless the staff don't like your group politically. Staff are fine with harassment, but they do what they can to censor users to create the illusion that their views are the norm. You will never hear worse writing advice on this site chanted like it's gospel. When it comes to group moderation, it's a two-headed coin flip whether the staff will side with the user being attacked and ganged up on for making something the group didn't like, or claim the victim's out of line for responding (insert adverb here) and side with the entitled abusers. Fimfiction is where intellectual writing critique goes to light itself aflame and commit seppuku. The genuine retards there think Past Sins and Fallout Equestria are what all good fanfictions should strive to be.

I'm convinced this is the reason why so many writers on that site are ignored (until a hate group targets them), and many are lavished with undue praise for getting about 100 followers and creating a hugbox of 10 circlejerkers for writing mediocre masturbatory crap. It's hard to get your work read at all without the cooperation of the Featured Box. This does not use an algorithm, and is used to advertise whatever stories site staff like; if you criticize this they'll use the excuse that algorithms are easily gamed once their rules are figured out.

There are groups on the site for stories of a specific length, which will take in only stories under 5k words, or over 50k words, or over 100k words, or over 1 million words. Writers are encouraged to needlessly bloat what they write in order to hopefully get these groups to notice their stories at all.

>reminder that serperior is a plant before it is a snake, that it photosynthesizes for nutrition instead of eating...
First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
Serperior's dex entries never state that it solely relies on photosynthesis. It would be pretty strange if it did, considering that it's been depicted eating stuff as I mentioned earlier.
>and that unlike actual predator pokemon it uses "foe" instead of prey"
Pokemon canonically fight for the lulz, which doesn't preclude Serperior from also preying on Pokemon for food. Swampert's FRLG dex entry uses the word "foe" as well, does that mean Swampert doesn't eat food either?
>further reminder that a snake's tract is lined with thousands of inwards-facing serrated spikes to deter escape and that theres nothing comforting about this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just a general reminder
>Fresh
Literal blob, circle, almost no features (Ditto, Milcery, Pyukumuku)
>In-Training
Still blobby and chibi but with slightly more features (Oddish, Poliwag, Budew)
>Rookie
Akin to a 2nd stage starter, tiny, fully formed yet simple (Dewott, Corvisquire, Sneasel)
>Champion
Makes a big jump, not gradual at all, becomes a big and proper monster, almost never humanoid (Arcanine, Drapion, Krookodile)
>Ultimate
This can go two ways, either it doubles down on the previous beast and repeats it except bigger and bulkier, or it becomes humanoid (so an Arcanine could become an Entei or an Incineroar)
>Mega
This can go three ways: become a holy being/knight or a huge ass mecha (sometimes it's literally just a human cosplaying, or it's at least humanoid-ish/bipedal), or become a beautiful sacred beast like a dragon or whale

>>52901250
Tbh I don't think I do anything special, ever since I was a toddler it's grown really fast (even when I was born I already had my head fully covered lol). My mom also has really long hair so I'm guessing it's genetic. It's currently at 103cm more or less, last year it had a sudden growth spurt out of nowhere (was at like 96 before), don't know why. If it helps, I use Elvive shampoo and conditioner, though sometimes (like twice a month because it's expensive and I need it to last) for the latter I use Tio Nacho instead. I also don't brush very often actually so I'm not constantly pulling at it, and when I do it's very gentle (start from the bottom/tips, with your other hand grab just a bit above it so you don't pull, once that's done grab a bit higher and brush again, continue until you're brushing all of it).
It does become a bit bothersome at times, like getting it stuck in handles without me noticing and having my head pulled back, accidentally sitting on it, bending over and the tips touching the floor (awful if it's wet... ), but other than that it's really nice and I want to see how long it can get tbqh. I can wrap it like a scarf during winter, or feel like some forest fairy when I'm naked at home and it falls all over my body, idk it's just really nice and soft, I can also do a lot of hair dos which is fun.

posts.com:
Reminder that no matter how much you beg for remakes, the Switch will never have every region that ever existed playable like the 3DS had by 2017.
It has no backwards compatibility and no Virtual Console.
While the Switch can easily last ten years, and Game Freak releases a new game every year, that leaves only around 5 opportunities to release games until 2027. And that’s assuming a new console doesn’t release in, say, 2025 or 2026 and Gamefreak doesn’t immediately jump onto it. Those 5 games have to include NEW games as well, naturally, whittling down the chances. 2023 can easily be taken up solely by SV DLC too, leaving 4 years instead of 5.
It would be physically impossible for them to remake Johto, Unova, Kalos, AND Alola in that timespan.
And no, there is no hope of Nintendo Switch Online suddenly gaining 3DS games. Honestly, even GBC seems like it’ll never happen. Which is insane, since SNES, Genesis and N64 games are on there.
The 3DS will continue to be the superior Pokemon console.
